column4: how can I set a shell script to run at boot completion time, and have it run as a specific user?
in /etc/rc.local: su -c '/path/to/script' username
Thanks!!

is there a similar file where I can place shell scripts that need to run before the system starts shutting down and sending sigterm to all the processes? (I am trying to figure out a way to gracefully shutdown or save state for virtual machines that are running at the time of a shutdown command)
/etc/rc.shutdown ;)
well that makes sense.
thanks
Wait, that's wrong, seems that's not in Ubuntu :/
yeah doesn't exist on my system :(
Okay, well, copy a random script to /etc/init.d and run "sudo update-rc.d myscript start 0 6". Kinda old way but I have no other ideas
can you explain what the latter parts of that are actually saying? "start 0 6"
start on runlevels 0 (system shutdown) and 6 (system reboot)
awesome, thanks
What do you want to do with the string exactly?
it is output from a command to show me what VM's are currently running. It gives the name and uuid.. I need to pass JUST the name to the vboxmanage command to shut off the vm gracefully
so it is like this "NAME" {uuid}
I need to strip off the {uuid} / parse out the name
Oh, heh. echo $string | sed -r 's/\{.*\}//g' | sed -r 's/\"//g' will do the trick.
can you explain that to me? it looks like magic.
Regular expressions... They are beyond explaining in a single message
okay, I'll take it. works flawlessly
thanks, if you know any good regular expressions tutorials, I'd love to take a look.
